subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Call of Cthulhu: Typo Report, paragraphs 4 and 6
msgSnippet: ... If you mean the second key utter , then, that s the Weak Vowel Merger; see
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> - "caricature" spelled "key utter roe it key utter cheer utter roe". I'd
> expect "key *et*", but, California native.

If you mean the second "key utter", then, that's the Weak Vowel Merger; see
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_history_of_English_high_front_vowels#Weak-vowel_merger>.
Most North Americans have it; Read surely did not. (A good diagnostic
word not mentioned in Wikipedia is "chicken": are the two vowels the same
(merger) or not (no merger)?

But the first "utter" looks terribly wrong: that's the stressed syllable,
and I don't know anyone who says "curricature". It's "ash" for me
and other people without the Mary-marry merger, and presumably "air"
for those who have it (probably including you).

--
You're a brave man! Go and break through the John Cowan
lines, and remember while you're out there cowan@...
risking life and limb through shot and shell, http://ccil.org/~cowan
we'll be in here thinking what a sucker you are!
--Rufus T. Firefly
